required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Clinical Evaluation to Confirm Safety and Efficacy of Sinuplasty in the Paranasal Sinuses (CLEAR)
clinical_study.official_title: Clinical Evaluation to Confirm Safety and Efficacy of Sinuplasty in the Paranasal Sinuses (CLEAR)

brief_summary.textblock: A multi-center, non-randomized, prospective post-market evaluation of sinuplasty in paranasal sinuses.

detailed_description.textblock:
Sinusitis is a common healthcare problem that significantly reduces quality of life for people around the world. Patients suffer from headache, facial discomfort, nasal congestion, nasal drainage, loss of the sense of smell and malaise. Sinusitis is responsible for major healthcare expenditure and loss of workplace productivity.
The rationale of this study is to collect data on the effectiveness and safety of balloon dilation of the Frontal, Maxillary and Sphenoid sinuses by treating patients and observing them for a six month period of time following the procedure. Six month follow-up data is important to demonstrate the effectiveness of balloon catheter dilation.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Sinuses With Patency of Sinus Ostium After Sinuplasty
primary_outcome.description: Patency of sinus ostium after sinuplasty will be determined by nasal endoscopic examination. The investigator will make a clinical judgment as to whether or not this has been achieved.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Adverse Events Following Sinuplasty Procedure
primary_outcome.description: Adverse event rate at 24 weeks: comprised of all observed peri-operative adverse events which were recorded on dedicated CRFs and any observed or patient-reported post-operative adverse events will be similarly recorded (through 24 week follow-up).

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants Experiencing Relief of Sinus Symptoms
secondary_outcome.description: To gain general insight into the ability of balloon catheter sinus ostial dilation to relieve sinus symptoms, scores from the pre-operative SNOT-20 evaluations were compared to scores from the post-procedure SNOT-20 evaluations at 24 weeks following the procedure. The number of participants who showed aggregate symptom relief are recorded here as having been successfully treated.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. Age 18 years and greater
2. Both male and female patients eligible
3. Diagnosis of chronic sinusitis that is not responsive to medical management
4. Planned endoscopic sinus surgery (recommended by PI, consented to by patient)
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Extensive sinonasal polyps
2. Extensive previous sinonasal surgery
3. Extensive sinonasal osteoneogenesis
4. Cystic fibrosis
5. Sampter's Triad (Aspirin sensitivity, Asthma, Sinonasal polyposis)
6. Sinonasal tumors or obstructive lesions
7. History of facial trauma that distorts sinus anatomy and precludes access to the sinus ostium
8. Ciliary dysfunction
9. Pregnant females

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Recruited from 3/2005 to 12/2005 in physician practice

outcome.title: Number of Sinuses With Patency of Sinus Ostium After Sinuplasty
outcome.description: Patency of sinus ostium after sinuplasty will be determined by nasal endoscopic examination. The investigator will make a clinical judgment as to whether or not this has been achieved.
outcome.population: Analysis per Protocol; based on all sinuses of subjects not lost to follow-up at 24 weeks

measure.title: Number of Sinuses With Patency of Sinus Ostium After Sinuplasty
measure.description: Patency of sinus ostium after sinuplasty will be determined by nasal endoscopic examination. The investigator will make a clinical judgment as to whether or not this has been achieved.
measure.population: Analysis per Protocol; based on all sinuses of subjects not lost to follow-up at 24 weeks

outcome.title: Number of Participants With Adverse Events Following Sinuplasty Procedure
outcome.description: Adverse event rate at 24 weeks: comprised of all observed peri-operative adverse events which were recorded on dedicated CRFs and any observed or patient-reported post-operative adverse events will be similarly recorded (through 24 week follow-up).
outcome.population: Analysis per protocol; based on subjects not lost to follow-up at 24 weeks

measure.title: Number of Participants With Adverse Events Following Sinuplasty Procedure
measure.description: Adverse event rate at 24 weeks: comprised of all observed peri-operative adverse events which were recorded on dedicated CRFs and any observed or patient-reported post-operative adverse events will be similarly recorded (through 24 week follow-up).
measure.population: Analysis per protocol; based on subjects not lost to follow-up at 24 weeks

outcome.title: Number of Participants Experiencing Relief of Sinus Symptoms
outcome.description: To gain general insight into the ability of balloon catheter sinus ostial dilation to relieve sinus symptoms, scores from the pre-operative SNOT-20 evaluations were compared to scores from the post-procedure SNOT-20 evaluations at 24 weeks following the procedure. The number of participants who showed aggregate symptom relief are recorded here as having been successfully treated.
outcome.population: All patients treated per protocol; includes all subjects not lost to follow-up at 24 weeks and who completed symptom questionnaire

measure.title: Number of Participants Experiencing Relief of Sinus Symptoms
measure.description: To gain general insight into the ability of balloon catheter sinus ostial dilation to relieve sinus symptoms, scores from the pre-operative SNOT-20 evaluations were compared to scores from the post-procedure SNOT-20 evaluations at 24 weeks following the procedure. The number of participants who showed aggregate symptom relief are recorded here as having been successfully treated.
measure.population: All patients treated per protocol; includes all subjects not lost to follow-up at 24 weeks and who completed symptom questionnaire

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: If requested by Sponsor, Investigator(s) shall delay the submission of any publication or presentation for up to sixty (60) days from the date of Sponsor’s request to permit the preparation and filing of related patent applications by Sponsor or for Sponsor to take other steps to protect its intellectual property interests.
